title-group.article-title: Carotenoid profiles of red- and yellow-colored arils of cultivars of Taxus baccata L. and Taxus × media Rehder

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Carotenoid profiles of red- and yellow-colored arils of cultivars of
Taxus baccata
L . and
Taxus × media Rehder

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
Roland Schex a, b , Veronika M. Lieb c , Christian Sch¨afer a , Ralf Schweiggert b , Christof B. Steingass
b, *

sec.p: ARTICLE INFO

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Dedication : Dedicated to our academic mentor Professor (em.) Dr. Dr. h.c. Reinhold Carle from the University of Hohenheim (Stuttgart, Germany ) on the occasion of his 70 th birthday.

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p:
Taxus baccata
L .
European yew
Identification
Quantitation
Xanthophyll ester retro -Carotenoids
Rhodoxanthin
Eschscholtzxanthin
ABSTRACT

The botanical delimitation of
Taxus species
and cultivars may be facilitated by characterizing the pigment profiles of their red- and yellow-fleshed arils. Therefore, we determined genuine carotenoid profiles of differently colored arils of seven defined cultivars of
Taxus baccata
L . and
Taxus × media Rehder.
In-depth HPLC-DAD-ESI/ APCI-MS
n
analyses revealed the presence of 43 carotenoids. Exceptional retro -carotenoids dominated the profiles of all samples assessed. Rhodoxanthin ( E/Z )-isomers were predominant in the red-colored arils, resulting in a rather unusual abundance of carotenoid isomers as expressed by ratios of up to 1.3:2.0:0.9 between (all- E )-, (6 Z )-, and (6 Z ,6 ′ Z )-rhodoxanthin, respectively. By contrast, the uncommon yellow arils of
Taxus baccata
L . ‘Lutea’ mainly contained eschscholtzxanthin ( E/Z )-isomers and esters. Total carotenoid concentrations ranged from 17.00 to 58.78 μg/g fresh weight across all samples assessed. Highest total rhodoxanthin concentrations of 51.33 ± 0.46 μg/g fresh weight were obtained from the red arils of
Taxus × media Rehder
‘Hicksii’. Overall,
Taxus
arils represent a promising source of carotenoids and, in particular, of retro -carotenoids with exceptional molecular structures and extraordinary absorption properties.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p:
Therefore, we present in-depth characterizations of carotenoid profiles from red- and yellow-colored arils of nine different yew trees, comprising seven defined cultivars of
T. baccata
and an interspecific hybrid
T. × media
. Carotenoids were identified and quantitated using high performance liquid chromatography-diode array detection (HPLC-DAD) and electrospray ionization (ESI) as well as atmospheric pressure chemical ionization (APCI) multi-stage mass-spectrometry (MS
n
). We sought to gain novel insights into the carotenoid profiles of yew arils, possibly facilitating the chemotaxonomic differentiation of
Taxus sp.
and cultivars and, ultimately, highlighting yew arils as promising natural source of carotenoids with high pigment concentrations.

sec.title: 2.1. Carotenoid identification by HPLC-DAD-ESI/APCI-MS n
2.1.1. HPLC-DAD-ESI-MSn experiments of free carotenoids
sec.p:
Compounds 1 , 2 , and 3 were identified by comparing their retention times, UV/vis spectra, and mass spectral data to those of authentic reference standards ( Table 2 ). The 5,6-diepoxy carotenoid (all- E )-violaxanthin ( 1 ) was eluting first in our chromatogram, displaying molecular ions [M] +• at m/z 600 and protonated molecules [M + H] + at m/z 601 in the ESI positive ion mode. Collision induced dissociation (CID) in the ESI(+)-MS 2 experiment resulted in fragment ions at m/z 583 ([M + H – H 2 O] + ) and m/z 565 ([M + H – 2 H 2 O] + ) due to the loss of water. Further product ions were determined at m/z 509 ([M + H – 92] + ) and m/z 491 ([M + H – H 2 O – 92] + ), presumably upon toluene elimination of 92 atomic mass units (amu) from the polyene chain according to
.

Compound 3 was unambiguously assigned to (all- E )-zeaxanthin. Molecular ions [M] +• at m/z 568 and protonated molecules [M + H] + at m/z 569 (both ESI(+)-MS 1 ) were detected at high abundance. In the ESI (+)-MS 2 experiment, we detected distinct fragment ions at m/z 551 ([M + H – H 2 O] + ), m/z 477 ([M + H – 92] + ), and m/z 476, being in accordance with those reported in the literature (
; Schex et al., 2018).

a Interspecific hybrid of
Taxus baccata
L. and
Taxus cuspidata Siebold & Zucc.

In the unusual yellow arils of
T. baccata
‘Lutea’, (all- E )-eschscholtzxanthin ( 21 ) as well as five geometrical isomers ( 10 , 13 , 15 , 17 , 20 ) and ten esters ( 28a , 33 , 35 , 37–43 ) of eschscholtzxanthin were the prevailing pigments ( Tables 2 and 3 ; Fig. 1b ). According to Appendino (1995), pigment profiles of golden-yellow arils from special cultivars of
T. baccata
have remained unknown. Heretofore, the dihydroxy- retro -carotenoid eschscholtzxanthin has been reported to occur in the petals of
Eschscholzia californica Cham.
, the leaves of
Buxus sempervirens
L ., and the arils of
Taxus cuspidata Siebold & Zucc.
(
;
;
,
). In our study, we substantiated the identification of (all- E )-eschscholtzxanthin in the yellow arils of
T. baccata
‘Lutea’ by obtaining a reference compound from the petals of
E. californica
that revealed matching retention times, UV/vis spectra, and MS data. Protonated molecules [M + H] + at m/z 567 were detected at low abundance for most eschscholtzxanthin ( E/Z )-isomers ( 10 , 15 , 17 , 20 , 21 ) in their ESI(+)-MS 1 spectra, apart from the lacking signal for one minor geometrical isomer ( 13 ). Distinct in-source fragments at m/z 549 ([M + H – H O] + ) were obtained for the 2 aforementioned peaks owing to spontaneous in-source elimination of water at C-3 (C-3 ′ ) of the ε- rings ( Fig. 2d ), by analogy to that observed for (all- E )-lutein as described above. In the ESI(+)-MS 2 experiment ( Fig. 2b ), CID of the [M + H – H O] + precursors resulted in fragment 2 ions at m/z 531 ([M + H – 2 H O] + ), m/z 457 ([M + H – H O 92] + ), 2 2 and m/z 439 ([M + H – 2 H O 92] + ) upon the loss of water and toluene 2 elimination, being in accordance with previous reports (Andrewes et al., 1979;
). The abundant product ions at m/z 475 ([M + H 2 H O 56] + ) and m/z 409 ([M + H 2 H O 122] + ) may be 2 2 assigned to the loss of water and subsequent retro -Diels-Alder fragmentation or cleavage of one of the two ε- rings, respectively. UV/vis spectra of eschscholtzxanthin ( E/Z )-isomers (see Table 2 and Fig. 3 ) revealed three distinct maxima at 442–448 nm , 466–472 nm (main λ max ), and 494–502 nm (DIII), with the exception of one geometrical isomer ( 17 ) having a shoulder at 498 nm . For instance, (all- E )-eschscholtzxanthin ( 21 ) showed absorption maxima at 448, 472, and 502 nm , being in accordance with the literature (Britton, 1995). In brief, UV/vis spectra of eschscholtzxanthin ( E/Z )-isomers clearly differed from those of rhodoxanthin by displaying a pronounced fine structure of the absorption band, not being found for rhodoxanthin ( E/Z )-isomers ( Fig. 3 ).

sec.p:

n
experiment.

sec.p:
R max Given t R and UV/vis data were acquired using the settings and instrumentation detailed in section 4.6, the MS data as specified in section 4.5. a D/Dratio of absorbance at the ‘( Z )-peak’ (D) and the main absorption maximum (D). B II, B II b D/Dratio of absorbance at maximum at longest wavelength (D) to D. III II, III II c In-source elimination of water ([M + H – H O] + ). 2 d Verified by an authentic reference standard. e Verified by a thermally isomerized reference standard of rhodoxanthin. f Verified by a reference compound extracted from the petals of
Eschscholzia californica Cham.

sec.title: 2.1.2. HPLC-DAD-APCI-MSn experiments of xanthophyll esters
sec.p:
Compounds 24 , 25 , 27 , 28b , and 30 were assigned to lutein esters according to their retention times as well as UV/vis and MS data compared to reference compounds obtained from marigold (
Tagetes sp.
) extract and literature data (
; Breithaupt et al., 2002). In the APCI() mode, molecular ions [M] • were detected at m/z 960 ( 25 ), m/z 988 ( 27 ), and m/z 1016 ( 30 ), matching with those of (all- E )-lutein laurate myristate, (all- E )-lutein dimyristate, and (all- E )--lutein myristate palmitate, respectively. In the APCI(+) mode, (all- E )--lutein dimyristate ( 27 ) revealed a single in-source fragment at m/z 761 ([M + H – 228] + ) owing to the spontaneous loss of myristic acid at the ε- ring. By contrast, lutein heterodiesters ( 25 , 30 ) revealed two distinct in-source fragments each, being detected at m/z 733 ([M + H – 228] + ) and m/z 761 ([M + H – 200] + ) for (all- E )-lutein laurate myristate ( 25 ) and m/z 761 ([M + H – 256] + ) and m/z 789 ([M + H – 228] + ) for (all- E )-lutein myristate palmitate ( 30 ) in accordance with the literature (
;
; Breithaupt et al., 2002). Co-elution of regioisomers of lutein heterodiesters presumably hindered their differentiation in our chromatogram compared to a previous report of
. In the APCI(+)-MS 2 experiment, characteristic product ions were detected at m/z 533, 441, and 411, further substantiating the assignment of all compounds to lutein esters ( 24 , 25 , 27 , 28b , 30 ). Moreover, UV/vis spectra (sh424, 446, and 474 nm ) resembled that of (all- E )-lutein ( 2 ), except for the absorption signal of compound 28b being overlaid by the unresolved eschscholtzxanthin myristate ( 28a ).

Compounds 28a , 33 , 35 , and 37–43 were assigned to esters of eschscholtzxanthin according to their UV/vis spectra, MS data, elution order in the chromatogram ( t R ), and the disappearance of respective peaks after saponification ( Table 3 and Fig. 1b ). Compound 28a was assigned to the monoester eschscholtzxanthin myristate. In the APCI(+) mode, we detected two in-source fragments at m/z 549 ([M + H – 228] + ) and m/z 759 ([M + H – H 2 O] + ) due to the spontaneous cleavage of myristic acid and water, respectively ( Fig. 2d ). CID revealed distinct fragment ions at m/z 667 ([M + H – H 2 O 92] + ) owing to toluene elimination. Moreover, characteristic product ions of eschscholtzxanthin were detected at m/z 531, 475, 439, and 409 as described above in more detail (c.f. Tables 2 and 3 ; see also Fig. 2b and c ). Compound 33 was tentatively assigned to an isomer of eschscholtzxanthin laurate myristate according to the detection of two distinct in-source fragments at m/z 731 ([M + H 228] + ) and m/z 759 ([M + H – 200] + ) in the APCI (+)-MS 1 spectrum. By analogy to the lutein heterodiesters described above ( 25 , 30 ), we hypothesized that resonance-stabilized in-source fragments of eschscholtzxanthin monoesters have been formed upon the neutral loss of fatty acyl moieties at C-3 (C-3 ′ ) of one of the two ε- rings. However, identifying eschscholtzxanthin diesters was specifically intricate because of this spontaneous in-source elimination of fatty acids, resulting in lacking signals of molecular ions [M] • and protonated molecules [M + H] + in the APCI negative and positive ion mode, respectively. In the APCI(+)-MS 2 spectrum of compound 33 , two respective product ions at m/z 639 ([M + H 228 92] + ) and m/z 667 ([M + H – 200 92] + ) appeared owing to the elimination of toluene and, therefore, further substantiated its identification as laurate myristate diester of eschscholtzxanthin. As a consequence of their elution after peak 33 ( t R = 14.9 min), compounds 35 and 37–43 ( t R ≥ 14.9 min) were also classified as diesters of eschscholtzxanthin. For the two most abundant eschscholtzxanthin diesters ( 39 , 42 ), single in-source fragments at m/z 759 (M + H 228) were detected in the APCI(+)-MS 1 spectra. Moreover, CID yielded typical fragment ions at m/z 667 ([M + H 228 92] + ) due to toluene elimination. Therefore, both compounds ( 39 , 42 ) were tentatively assigned to ( E/Z )-isomers of eschscholtzxanthin dimyristate.

t , retention time; λ , UV/vis absorption maxima; sh, shoulder; n.d., not detected; * base peak in the APCI(+)-MS
n
experiment.

R max Given t R an pled UV/vis data were acquired using the settings and instrumentation detailed in section 4.6, the MS data as specified in section 4.5. a D/D, ratio of absorbance at the ‘( Z )-peak’ (D) and the main absorption maximum (D).
B II B II b D/Dratio of absorbance at maximum at longest wavelength (D) to D.
III II, III II c In-source elimination of water ([M + H – H O] + ).
2 d In-source

e Verified by a reference compound extracted from the flesh of
Carica papaya
L.

Five eschscholtzxanthone esters ( 29 , 31 , 32 , 34 , 36 ) were identified in the red-colored arils ( Table 3 and Fig. 1a ). In the APCI(+)-MS 1 experiment, in-source fragments at m/z 547 ([M + H fatty acid] + ) were detected at high abundance for all eschscholtzxanthone esters owing to the spontaneous in-source elimination of fatty acids as described above for eschscholtzxanthin esters. In addition, APCI()-MS 1 experiments yielded signals at m/z 773 ([M H]) and m/z 774 ([M] • ) for the compounds 32 and 34 , thus being assigned to ( E/Z )-isomers of eschscholtzxanthone myristate. Even though no distinct signals of the molecular ions were detected, compounds 29 , 31 , and 36 were also classified as esters of eschscholtzxanthone on the basis of their presence before and absence after sample saponification. APCI(+)-MS 2 experiments of the compounds 29 , 31 , 32 , 34 , and 36 revealed fragment ions at m/z 491 ([M + H fatty acid 56] + ) and m/z 455 ([M + H fatty acid 92] + ) due to retro -Diels-Alder fragmentation of the ε- ring and toluene elimination, respectively. Noteworthy, product ions at m/z 463 ([M + H fatty acid 84]) + , possibly deriving from the fragmentation of the ε- ring carrying the oxo-group, were detected as observed during CID of rhodoxanthin. UV/vis spectra of the assigned eschscholtzxanthone esters did not exhibit a pronounced fine structure but rather single maxima ranging from 478 to 486 nm (see Table 3 and Fig. 3 ), being a characteristic feature of carotenoids with conjugated oxo-groups in the molecular structure according to Chac´on-Ordo´˜nez et al. (2017) and Britton (1995).

sec.title: 2.2. Carotenoid quantitation by HPLC-DAD
sec.p:
Carotenoid concentrations in μg/g fresh weight (fr. wt) of red- and yellow-colored arils of various defined cultivars of
T. baccata
and the interspecific hybrid
T. × media
are compiled in Tables 4 and 5 , respectively. Overall, the hitherto unprecedented quantitation of carotenoids in yew arils revealed total concentrations of 17.00–58.78 μg/g fr. wt across all samples assessed. According to Britton and Khachik (2009), the aforementioned concentrations classify as high (5–20 μg/g fr. wt) to very high ( > 20 μg/g fr. wt). Carotenoid concentrations of our yew arils were in the range of those reported earlier for various tropical crops, e.g., peach palm fruits (6.9–138.95 μg/g fr. wt), mamey sapote (37.86–80.76 μg/g fr. wt), and cashew apples (6.93–52.78 μg/g fr. wt) with differently colored flesh and peel (
;
; Chacon-Ord´o´nez ˜et al., 2017). Furthermore, yew arils of our study exhibited higher carotenoid concentrations than those found in several other carotenoid-rich fruits and vegetables like pineapple and sweet potato, being previously reported to contain 0.29–5.65 and 2.4–24.6 μg/g fr. wt, respectively (
;
). Therefore, we characterized the arils of
T. baccata
and
T. × media
as rich source of carotenoids that is widely distributed in the Euro-Mediterranean region.

Genuine carotenoid profiles of all red-colored arils were clearly dominated by rhodoxanthin ( E/Z )-isomers, accumulating to a sum of 19.46–51.33 μg/g fr. wt ( Table 4 ) and, therefore, representing a rhodoxanthin source with high to very high concentrations (Britton and Khachik, 2009). Rhodoxanthin accounted for strikingly high 87–99% of the total carotenoids across all red samples. Red arils of
T. × media
‘Hicksii’ (51.33 ± 0.46 μg/g fr. wt) were characterized by significantly higher total rhodoxanthin concentrations than those of aril samples obtained from cultivars of
T. baccata
. (all- E )-Rhodoxanthin prevailed in the arils of
T. × media
‘Hicksii’ and
T. baccata
‘Elegantissima’, whereas (6 Z )-rhodoxanthin was the most abundant ( E/Z )-isomer of red arils from the remaining cultivars. On the basis of their mean values, (all- E )-, (6 Z )-, and (6 Z ,6 ′ Z )-rhodoxanthin were determined to be deposited in ratios ranging from 2.1:2.0:0.7 (
T. × media
‘Hicksii’,
T. baccata
‘Elegantissima’) to 1.3:2.0:0.9 (
T. baccata
1). Therefore, our study revealed that rhodoxanthin isomers with ( Z )-configured exocyclic double bonds abundantly occurred in yew arils, resulting in similar ratios of 2:2:1 to 1:2:1 between (all- E )-, (6 Z )-, and (6 Z ,6 ′ Z )-rhodoxanthin as found earlier in the leaves of several gymnosperms (
), the bird plumage of
Ilicura militaris ( Hudon et al., 2007 )
, and the red-colored berries of
Lonicera sp.
(
). Nevertheless, in yew arils we did not observe ratios of up to 1:2:2 as reported previously for the thermally induced ( E/Z )-isomer equilibria of dissolved rhodoxanthin at 50–70 ◦ C (
). In future studies, carotenoid profiling of yew arils at earlier maturity stages may further elucidate the evolution of ratios between geometrical ( E/Z )-isomers of rhodoxanthin.
Values represent mean ± standard deviation. Significant differences ( p ≤ 0.05) within a row are indicated by different letters.
n.d., not detected; tr., traces.
a Calculated as sum of rhodoxanthin ( E/Z )-isomers and eschscholtzxanthone esters.

Eschscholtzxanthone esters further contributed to the high concentration of retro -carotenoids in all red-colored samples assessed, in total amounting to 19.48–54.46 μg/g fr. wt. The highest concentration of eschscholtzxanthone esters was obtained from
T. × media
‘Hicksii’ (3.12 ± 0.18 μg/g fr. wt) as well as
T. baccata
‘Hessei’ (1.72 ± 0.04 μg/g fr. wt) and ‘Washingtonii’ (1.31 ± 0.01 μg/g fr. wt). Furthermore, significantly higher levels of (all- E )-β- cryptoxanthin myristate were determined in
T. × media
‘Hicksii’ (2.94 ± 0.05 μg/g fr. wt) and
T. baccata
‘Hessei’ (2.55 ± 0.11 μg/g fr. wt) compared to those found in all other red-colored yew arils. Noteworthy, the cultivar ‘Dovastonii Aurea’ showed the lowest total carotenoid concentration (20.33 ± 0.51 μg/g fr. wt) but a significantly higher quantity of (all- E )-lutein (0.56 ± 0.06 μg/g fr. wt) than those of the remaining red aril samples (0.17–0.25 μg/g fr. wt). In brief, carotenoid concentrations of red-colored arils differed remarkably between the cultivars of
Taxus sp.
assessed in our study, in particular, those of the interspecific hybrid
T. × media
‘Hicksii’.

Yellow-colored arils of the cultivar
T. baccata
‘Lutea’ were characterized by a clearly differing carotenoid profile compared to those of
Taxus sp.
and cultivars bearing red-colored arils, resulting in a distinctive morphological differentiating factor, i.e., the visual color appearance of yew arils ( c.f. arils in Fig. 1a and b ). Total carotenoid concentrations of yellow arils ranged from 17.00 ± 0.52 to 19.55 ± 1.00 μg/g fr. wt, thus being significantly lower than those of red-colored arils with
T. baccata ‘Dovastonii
Aurea’ (20.33 ± 0.51 μg/g fr. wt) being the exception. The latter showed that the apparent color difference between yellow- and red-colored arils may be primarily assigned to the carotenoid profiles rather than the total carotenoid concentration. In particular, when considering the bathochromic shifts of the UV/vis absorption spectra owing to stepwise dehydration of the hydroxy groups of eschscholtzxanthin (yellow arils) to eschscholtzxanthone and rhodoxanthin (red arils) and the resulting prolongation of the chromophore by up to two oxo-groups ( Fig. 3 ).

In the yellow-colored arils of
T. baccata
‘Lutea’, eschscholtzxanthin amounted in total to 14.83–17.36 μg/g fr. wt and, thus, accounted for 87–89% of the total carotenoids. So far, eschscholtzxanthin has been reported to be predominant in the petals of California poppy (
E. californica
) with 32% of the total carotenoids (
). Free, i.e., non-esterified, (all- E )-eschscholtzxanthin prevailed in our yellow-colored arils with concentrations of 5.73 ± 0.31 and 8.14 ± 0.41 μg/g fr. wt. Moreover, yellow arils of
T. baccata
‘Lutea’ abundantly contained eschscholtzxanthin isomers (2.58–2.61 μg/g fr. wt) and esters (6.49–6.64 μg/g fr. wt). In previous reports on
E. californica
, biosynthetic pathways to eschscholtzxanthin have been proposed via zeaxanthin, antheraxanthin, and a trihydroxy- retro -carotenoid (
;
). (all- E )-Zeaxanthin was quantitated in our yellow-colored arils in small amounts (0.09–0.30 μg/g fr. wt), whereas antheraxanthin and the aforementioned trihydroxy- retro -carotenoid were not detected as compared to an authentic reference standard and the extract from petals of
E. californica
, respectively. However, the presence of such biosynthetic precursors of eschscholtzxanthin in the yellow arils of
T. baccata
‘Lutea’ cannot be excluded on the basis of the available data and might be elucidated by carotenoid profiling of aril samples at earlier maturity stages. By contrast, it was clearly shown that retro -carotenoids featuring oxo-groups in their molecular structure, e.g., eschscholtzxanthone and rhodoxanthin, were not detected in the yellow arils of
T. baccata
‘Lutea’ (see section 2.1). Therefore, we hypothesized by reverse analogy, that rhodoxanthin synthase is either missing or apparently showing insufficient activity in the arils of
T. baccata
‘Lutea’. Hence, the tentative biosynthetic pathway from eschscholtzxanthin to eschscholtzxanthone and rhodoxanthin might be hampered in yellow-colored arils. This major difference in the carotenoid profile of our yew arils resulted in colors ranging from yellow and golden-orange for arils of
T. baccata
‘Lutea’ to bright red for those of the remaining yew trees assessed.

sec.title: 2.3. Light microscopy
3. Conclusions
sec.p:
Our study reports an in-depth carotenoid profiling of red- and yellow-colored arils of defined cultivars of two
Taxus sp.
, i.e.,
T. baccata
and the interspecific hybrid
T. × media
. Carotenoid profiles of yew arils were dominated by exceptional retro -carotenoids. In red-fleshed arils, we assigned nine rhodoxanthin ( E/Z )-isomers and five eschscholtzxanthone esters. Rhodoxanthin ( E/Z )-isomers amounted to a maximum of 51.33 ± 0.46 μg/g fr. wt, being predominantly represented by (all- E )-, (6 Z )-, and (6 Z ,6 ′ Z )-rhodoxanthin in different ratios. By contrast, ( E/Z )- isomers and esters of eschscholtzxanthin were the major pigments in the yellow-fleshed arils of
T. baccata
‘Lutea’. The high total carotenoid concentrations of 17.00–58.78 μg/g fr. wt across all samples assessed may support valorizing yew arils as promising source of carotenoids and, in particular, of retro -carotenoids with exceptional molecular structures and extraordinary absorption properties. Although arils of
Taxus sp.
have historically been consumed by humans, non-toxicity and, thus, safety of yew aril consumption needs to be ensured prior to define efficient downstream processing for obtaining natural carotenoid extracts from yew arils. Further insights into the ultrastructure of yew aril plastids and the deposition of carotenoids might be elucidated in continuative studies using transmission electron microscopy and in vitro digestion models as established previously for other plant tissues (
; Chac´on-Ordo´nez ˜et al., 2016). Moreover, chemotaxonomic chromoplast characterization beyond carotenoid profiles might be used as additional marker to substantiate the differentiation of
Taxus sp.
as has been reported by
on the basis of e.g., chloroplast genotyping and fingerprinting of deoxyribonucleic acid.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: Values represent mean ± standard deviation. Significant differences ( p ≤ 0.05) within a row are indicated by different letters.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: a Calculated as sum of ( E/Z )-isomers and esters of eschscholtzxanthin.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: b Calculated as sum of esters of lutein and eschscholtzxanthin.

sec.title: 4.1. Reagents
sec.p: Diethyl ether, ethyl acetate, n -hexane, methanol, tert -butyl methyl ether ( t BME), and potassium hydroxide were purchased from Merck (Darmstadt, Germany ). Butylated hydroxytoluene and calcium carbonate were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich (Taufkirchen, Germany ) and Fluka Chemie (Buchs, Switzerland ), respectively. All chemicals were at least of HPLC or analytical grade. Purified water (PURELAB Ultra, ELGA LabWater, High Wycombe, United Kingdom ; Milli-Q Gradient, Merck) was used throughout the experiments.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
4.2. Arils of cultivars of Taxus baccata L. and
Taxus × media Rehder

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p:
In November 2018 , arils were harvested from the yew tree collection planted in the Hohenheim Gardens (Stuttgart, Germany ). Red-colored arils were collected from two
Taxus baccata
L. ( Taxaceae ) yew trees and four defined cultivars, i.e., ‘Dovastonii Aurea’, ‘Washingtonii’, ‘Elegantissima’, and ‘Hessei’. The sampling further comprised red-fleshed arils of the interspecific hybrid
Taxus × media Rehder
‘Hicksii’ ( Taxaceae ). Yellow-colored arils were harvested from two yew trees of the cultivar
T. baccata
‘Lutea’. Planting years and GPS coordinates of sample specimens are listed in Table 1 as available online in the information system on plants of the Hohenheim Gardens (
). Three individual samples ( n = 3) consisting of at least 10 arils were collected from each yew tree. Arils were frozen after harvest using liquid nitrogen, vacuum-sealed in laminated foil, and stored at 20 ◦ C until carotenoid extraction.

sec.title: 4.5. Carotenoid identification by HPLC-DAD-ESI/APCI-MS n analyses
sec.p: For compound identification, we pooled several extracts of red- and yellow-colored arils, respectively. In case that saponification was deemed appropriate, we followed the protocol as reported by Schex et al. (2018). Briefly, the dried extracts were re-dissolved in 2 mL diethyl ether and 2 mL methanolic potassium hydroxide (10%, w/v ), flushed with nitrogen, and saponified for 3 h under continuous stirring and light exclusion. After washing the saponified extracts twice with 2 mL water, the organic phases were collected, evaporated to dryness using a gentle nitrogen stream, and re-dissolved for HPLC analyses as described in section 4.4.

A Thermo Fisher Accela HPLC series was equipped with a diode array detector and coupled to a LXQ mass spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, San Jose, CA, USA ). The injection volume was 20 μL. Carotenoids were chromatographically separated at 23 ◦ C on a C 30 reversed phase column (150 × 3.0 mm i.d., 3 μ m particle size, YMC Europe, Dinslaken, Germany ) protected by a YMC guard cartridge of the same material. HPLC eluents were mixtures of methanol/ t BME/water (eluent A, 90:8:2, v / v / v ; eluent B, 20:78:2, v / v / v ). Following elution gradient was applied at a constant flow rate of 0.5 mL/min: Isocratic at 100% A (1 min), 100% to 0% A (12 min), isocratic hold at 0% A (3 min), 0% to 100% A (0.1 min), isocratic at 100% A (4.9 min). Total run time was 21 min. UV/vis absorption spectra were recorded at 270–800 nm . Ratios of DIII/DII (%) and DB/DII (%) were determined according to Britton (1995).

For MS
n
analyses of free carotenoids, the aforementioned HPLC-MS system was equipped with an ESI source, operating in positive ion mode at a scan range of m/z 150–1500 for MS 1 spectra. Nitrogen was used as sheath, auxiliary, and sweep gas at flow rates of 40, 5, and 5 arbitrary units, respectively. Further settings were as follows: Spray voltage, 5000 V; capillary temperature, 300 ◦ C ; capillary voltage, 6.0 V; tube lens, 45 V. CID was achieved by applying a normalized collision energy of 35% and an isolation width of m/z 3.

MS
n
analyses of xanthophyll esters were performed using an APCI source in negative and positive ion mode, a MS 1 scan range of m/z 300–1500, and the sheath, auxiliary, and sweep gas at the aforementioned conditions. Further settings: Vaporizer temperature, 350 ◦ C ; discharge current, 5 μA; capillary temperature, 300 ◦ C ; capillary voltage, 6.0 V; tube lens, 45 V; normalized collision energy (CID), 35%; isolation width, m/z 3. Xcalibur software (version 2.0.7 SP1) was used for data acquisition (Thermo Fisher Scientific).
sec.title: 4.3. Light microscopy
sec.p:
Light micrographs were taken using an Axioskop microscope (Zeiss, Feldbach, Germany ) equipped with an Axiocam 105 color camera (Zeiss, Gottingen ¨, Germany ). Fresh, freehand tissue samples of red (
T. baccata
L . ‘Hessei’) and yellow (
T. baccata
L . ‘Lutea’) arils were assessed using bright field and phase contrast. Polarized light was used to characterize the deposition of carotenoids in the chromoplasts.

Compounds were assigned by comparing their retention times ( t R ), UV/vis absorption spectra, and mass spectra to those of authentic reference standards and thermally isomerized samples derived thereof. Moreover, spectral data was compared to the literature.

sec.title: 4.4. Extraction of carotenoids
4.6. Carotenoid quantitation by HPLC-DAD analyses
sec.p: The extraction work-up was conducted under reduced light exposure to inhibit carotenoid isomerization and degradation. The frozen arils were separated manually from the seeds and homogenized using a Polytron PT 1300 D disperser (Kinematica, Lucerne , Switzerland ) at 15 000 rpm for 2.5 min. Each aril puree was analyzed in duplicate. Aliquots of 320 ± 40 mg and ca. 50 mg calcium carbonate were mixed with 2 mL of a mixture of methanol/ethyl acetate/ n -hexane (1:1:1, v/v/v ) containing 0.2 g /L butylated hydroxytoluene as antioxidant. Carotenoids were extracted for 10 min in an ice-cooled ultrasonic bath. After adding 1 mL water, samples were centrifuged and the organic phases were collected. The remainders were re-extracted 2–3 times using 1 mL of the aforementioned extraction solvent in the ultrasonic bath for 5 min. Organic phases were collected, evaporated to dryness using a gentle nitrogen stream, and stored at 20 ◦ C until further analyses. For HPLC analyses, dried extracts were re-dissolved in t BME/methanol (1:1, v/v ), membrane-filtered (polytetrafluoroethylene, 0.45 μm, Pall Life Sciences, Ann Arbor, MI, USA ), and filled into amber glass vials.

Carotenoids were extracted as described in section 4.4 and quantitated using an Agilent series 1100 HPLC system coupled to a G1315A DAD (Agilent, Waldbronn, Germany ) and the above-described chromatographic conditions. The injection volume was 10 μL. Linear calibration curves of (all- E )-β- carotene ( 0.03–31.56 mg / L ; R 2 = 0.99998), ( E/Z )-rhodoxanthin ( 0.05–13.56 mg / L ; R 2 = 0.99987), and (all- E )-zeaxanthin ( 0.04–13.56 mg / L ; R 2 = 0.99995) were used for quantitation. Stock solution concentrations were determined spectrophotometrically using molar extinction coefficients as reported by Britton (1995). A scan range of 210–700 nm was used to record UV/vis spectra. Rhodoxanthin ( E/Z )-isomers were monitored at 488, 496, and 504 nm . Eschscholtzxanthone esters were detected at 475 and 488 nm , being quantitated using the rhodoxanthin calibration. Eschscholtzxanthin ( E/Z )-isomers and the respective esters were detected at 465 and 475 nm . All other carotenoids including their esters were monitored at 450 nm . β- Cryptoxanthin, eschscholtzxanthin, lutein, and violaxanthin as well as respective geometrical isomers and esters were quantitated using the calibration curve of (all- E )-zeaxanthin. Molecular weight correction factors were applied if necessary. Esters were quantitated as equivalent of the respective free carotenoid.

sec.title: 4.7. Statistics
sec.p: Univariate statistical analyses were performed using Minitab 18 (State College, PA, USA ). Normality and homogeneity of variances of data sets were evaluated by Ryan-Joiner’ s ( p ≤ 0.05) and Levene’ s test ( p ≤ 0.05), respectively. Tukey’ s test ( p ≤ 0.05) was applied to determine significant differences between data showing normal distribution and homogenous variances. Data sets without normal distribution were applied to the Kruskal-Wallis test ( p ≤ 0.05).

sec.title: Declaration of competing interest
sec.p: The authors declare the following financial interests/personal relationships which may be considered as potential competing interests: R. Schex and C . Sch¨afer work for a commercial manufacturer of carotenoids (DSM Nutritional Products).
